definition: lit. it takes a long time to make a big pot (idiom); fig. a great talent matures slowly/in the fullness of time a major figure will develop into a pillar of the state/Rome wasn't built in a day
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
device/tool/utensil/CL:臺|台[tai2]
evening/night/late
surname Cheng
to succeed/to finish/to complete/to accomplish/to become/to turn into/to be all right/OK!/one tenth

sentences.english: But Li is a late bloomer.
Never forget, delay does not always mean denial.
sentences.chinese: 永遠記住，大器晚成不意味着一無所成。

sentences.english: Murakami was a late bloomer, writing his first work at age 29.
sentences.chinese: 村上春樹大器晚成，29歲才寫他的第一部作品。

sentences.english: Many great men were late bloomers in life.
sentences.chinese: 很多偉人都是大器晚成型的。

definition: to win success and recognition (idiom)
to hit the big time
both fame and fortune (idiom)/both virtue and reward
to make one's name/to become famous
to be successful in business/professional success
to amaze the world with a single brilliant feat (idiom); an overnight celebrity
lit. to have accumulated knowledge and deliver it slowly (idiom)/good preparation is the key to success/to be well prepared
bitterness finishes, sweetness begins (idiom); the hard times are over, the good times just beginning
first half of one's life
thirty years old and therefore independent (idiom, from Confucius)
to break clear of all the troubles and hardships/to achieve success/to make it
unaccomplished/mediocre/feckless
aged thirty (see 三十而立)
the time comes, fortune turns (idiom); to have a lucky break/things change for the better
extraordinary talent/exceptionally gifted
brimming over with talent (esp. literary)/brilliant
